ref: 9710 *macyatē ʻ is produced, grows, is kindled, is rubbed ʼ. 2. *macya -- . 3. Pp. *makta -- . [mácatē ʻ grinds, is arrogant ʼ, máñcatē ʻ id., grows high, shines ʼ Dhātup. <-> It is difficult in NIA. to separate forms of √mac meaning ʻ excite, excited ʼ from √mad (māˊdyati, mattá -- ) of which in MIA. pres. st. majj -- was partially replaced by macc -- after the type sitta -- ~ siccaï. -- The meanings in NIA. support IE. origin (Gk. ma/ssw, &c.) IEW 730. -- √mac]
S. macaṇu ʻ to be excited, increase, rise to full strength, be fattened ʼ, caus. macāiṇu;
L. maccaṇ ʻ to burn brightly, be excited ʼ,
awāṇ. maccuṇ ʻ to rise, be kindled (of fire) ʼ;
P. maccṇā ʻ to be stirred up, be made ʼ, macāuṇā ʻ to kindle, produce ʼ;
N. maccinu ʻ to be flourished, be made ʼ, macāunu ʻ to lift up, flourish ʼ;
A. masiba ʻ to rub ʼ (or < mr̥śáti as loanword from a dialect preserving -- s -- );
H. mã̄cnā ʻ to be begun ʼ, macānā ʻ to raise up, produce ʼ; O
Marw. maṁcāvaï ʻ creates, brings about ʼ;
G. macvũ ʻ to swell ʼ, macāvvũ ʻ to set on foot, make ʼ;
M. māċṇẽ ʻ to fill up ʼ, maċṇẽ ʻ to swell ʼ, maċaviṇẽ ʻ to make ʼ; --
Si. masanavā, maha˚ ʻ to sew, fetter ʼ (EGS 130 wrongly < myákṣati)?
